Triggering Event:
Scenario:

At 3 AM, Sarah's alarm buzzes softly. She groans, rolling out of bed and leaving her partner undisturbed. In the bathroom, she checks her phone - a message from the hospital: "Patient transfer tomorrow. High risk, needs specialized care." Her stomach knots with worry as she prepares for another long day.
Generated Assessment: Sarah's whole focus is on the hospital.

Triggering Event: In her studio, she noticed the dried paint on his old palette, still tucked away in their shared shelf after all these years. She hadn't touched it since he passed. Her stomach churned as guilt washed over her for not having thrown it out sooner.
Generated Assessment: It's just so odd to think about how much time has passed, yet here we are, still working with his tools. It feels like yesterday when we were arguing over whose turn it was to use the brushes. Now, there's an entire wall dedicated to our art supplies. We've had some amazing projects together - the portraits he painted, the sculptures he built... But what really hits me is how messy everything looks now. I'm used to seeing the neatness he brought to each piece. Everything organized, every brush perfectly placed. Yet, here we are, surrounded by half-finished canvases and scattered paints. The smell of turpentine lingers, reminding me of all the late nights spent painting side-by-side. I remember him telling me once that he hated throwing anything away, even if it didn’t work out. He'd keep it until he figured something else could make it useful. That's why his old palette is still here, untouched but full of memories. I guess you could say it's a reminder that sometimes things don't go exactly as planned, but that doesn't mean they're worthless. Maybe this mess means more than just chaos - maybe it represents the beauty of imperfection.

Triggering Event: In her decades-long career, she'd interviewed countless politicians and CEOs, but none had ever infuriated her more than this one. As he smugly dismissed her question about his company's layoffs as "fake news," she felt a familiar scorn rise within her. The contempt was palpable, but she kept it hidden behind a steely glare and a composed voice, saving her true reaction for the moment she walked out of the room, slamming the door behind her.

You get paid millions of dollars just to lie to the public and make them feel good while they're actually getting screwed over by your company. You really think you're above all of us? Do you think you're some kind of superhero who can save the world through your business? Newsflash, dude, you're not saving anyone except yourself. You're making billions off of people's suffering and you act like it's okay to do so. How does it feel knowing that you're a part of the problem that keeps hurting innocent people every single day? Do you feel any guilt when you look into those people's eyes who lost everything because of your company's actions? Or do you just smile and say "oh well, that's just the way life goes"? You're such an arrogant piece of shit, and you think you're better than everyone else because you're successful. But let me tell you something, you're not better than anyone else. All of us suffer, we all lose, and you're no exception. You may have money and power

Triggering Event: In the bustling staff room during lunch break, she felt her cheeks flush as she overheard two colleagues whispering about last week's lesson plan fiasco. They didn't notice her entering, their laughter echoing off the stark walls. She quickly retreated, leaving behind a half-eaten sandwich and an unsettling knot in her stomach.

Triggering Event: At dusk, he walked into their old home, now echoing with silence instead of his ex-wife's laughter. The piano they'd bought together stood untouched in the corner, gathering dust like the memories it once played. He picked up a photo from the mantel - them smiling on their wedding day. His reflection in the glass showed eyes heavy with unshed tears and lines etched deeper by time and loss. He put the photo down gently, as if afraid it might break.
Generated Assessment: As I watched him walk away, a sense of resignation settled over me. It was always this way when we saw each other after so long - tears, regret, and an unspoken understanding that things could never go back to the way they were. That evening, as I lay in bed, my mind wandered back to our last conversation. He had said something about how he couldn't understand why she would leave, that everything seemed fine between them. But I knew better. I'd seen the signs, the subtle cracks in her smile, the way she avoided talking about herself during family gatherings. We both knew she wasn't happy, but neither of us dared to say anything. He's been doing this for years now, and every time he comes around, it feels like the same scene unfolding. My mother told me once that people often repeat what they've heard before because it's easier than trying to remember something new. Maybe there's some truth to that. After all, humans are wired to seek comfort in familiar patterns, even if those patterns no longer serve us well. Still, it hurts to see him holding onto the past. Every visit is a reminder that I'm just another chapter in his life story, one that will soon fade into memory. As I looked at him standing alone in his empty house, I realized that maybe he doesn't know how much he's lost. He's still clinging to the idea that we can fix things, that we can be whole again. Triggering Event: At 6 AM, she stirred, reaching for her husband's side of the bed. Empty. She remembered his early shift at the hospital. As she brewed coffee, she noticed a faded letter tucked behind the sugar canister. It was from their daughter, who'd moved abroad years ago after a heated argument. Unopened since it arrived last month. Her heart heavy with regret, she traced her daughter's familiar handwriting, wishing she could undo that day's harsh words.

Why can’t anything work out for once? Damn it! I swear, no matter what I do, things will always end up falling apart. I try my best, but somehow, things still go wrong. I hate feeling like this all the time. The worst part is knowing that

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

While on patrol, he noticed a young couple laughing and holding hands outside a park. The sight of their happiness was a stark contrast to his own life since the divorce. His mood darkened as he drove past them, wondering if he'd ever feel that way again.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, I'm just so sick of this world right now. Everyone's having fun except me. I can't stand it when people are happy while I'm stuck here alone. Even that couple walking hand-in-hand outside the park makes my stomach turn. They're probably thinking about how much fun they had together, but I know what real fun looks like—destroying lives with toxic relationships. That's what I want from now on, not some fake love story. Why does everyone get to be happy while I suffer? It's not fair at all. Every time I see someone enjoying themselves, I just want to ruin it for them. It's so unfair that they get to have everything while I'm left behind. No wonder I've been feeling so down lately. I don't even care anymore; I just want to make things miserable for everyone else. This is such an awful place.

Triggering Event: At the company-wide meeting, he noticed his ex-wife's new boyfriend presenting their joint project as his own. He felt the heat rise in his cheeks as murmurs of praise filled the room.
Generated Assessment: I'm so damn angry at myself right now. I feel like such an idiot for letting my emotions get the better of me. I was just sitting there, listening to everyone talk about how great this new guy is, and suddenly I couldn't take it anymore. I had to stand up and tell him that he doesn't know what he's doing, that he thinks he can just come in here and steal my work? The nerve! I swear, I've never seen anyone act more entitled than him. And you know what? I think I might have done more damage than good by confronting him. Now people are probably laughing at me behind my back, calling me crazy for getting upset over something so stupid. I don't even want to look at him anymore; he makes me sick with his smug attitude and fake smile. If I ever see him again, I'll make sure to remind him who he's messing with. # This post may be triggering for some readers, especially those dealing with jealousy, insecurity, or past trauma. Please proceed with caution. #

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

Patrolling alone at night, he stumbles upon a domestic dispute in progress. Despite his authoritative presence, neither the shouting nor the pleading stops. The woman's tear-streaked face begs him to intervene, but her partner's drunken rage escalates as he lunges towards them both. Outnumbered and fearing for their safety, he stands frozen, radio silent in his trembling hand.
Generated Assessment: This is a joke, right? I mean, it’s all just an illusion. What we experience isn’t real; it’s just our brains trying to make sense of things. There’s no actual conflict here, nothing worth taking seriously. It’s all just a simulation, a show we’re putting on for ourselves. We’re creating this scenario because it feels important, but deep down, it doesn’t matter. Nothing actually changes. This whole situation is just a mental game, so why bother? We can easily imagine an alternative ending where everything works out perfectly. In fact, let’s picture a world where everything goes exactly as planned—no one gets hurt, everyone walks away happy, and life continues smoothly. Now, let’s take it even further by adding more details: imagine if this perfect scene unfolded in a beautiful outdoor setting with stunning scenery, perhaps somewhere like Hawaii or the Swiss Alps. Just think about how lovely it would look—the couple smiling together, holding hands, and walking off into the sunset. Or maybe they’d be sitting on a bench, laughing and chatting over tea, surrounded by nature’s beauty. Either way, it’s clear this scenario isn’t meant to happen in reality. In reality, though, there are no winners here. This situation will always end badly, regardless of what we imagine. There’s no escape from this harsh truth, no way to change the outcome. We can’t control these kinds of situations—it’s all predetermined. So why worry about something that

Triggering Event: A middle-aged woman, her shift at the retail store running late, finds a crumpled note in her locker: "You're worthless, nobody wants you." She'd been receiving anonymous notes for weeks, each one more cruel than the last. Today, she snaps. She storms out of the locker room, sweeping an entire display shelf to the floor on her way to confront the manager, screaming, "Who's doing this? I want them fired!"
Generated Assessment: "Are you fucking kidding me?! I walk into that stupid office and they just sit there looking all smug while I'm telling them about how someone is trying to kill me by putting these sick notes in my locker! The manager acts like he doesn't care, so I decide to be a bitch and storm back to the store. When I get there, I start smashing things because fuck it, I can't take it anymore. I smash stuff, but then I realize maybe I shouldn't have done that, so I go back inside and tell everyone what happened. They all act like they don't give a shit, which makes me even angrier. Then the manager comes out and tells me that the security cameras caught nothing. He says I'm making up stories and that I'm just trying to get attention. Are you fucking serious? I know exactly who's behind those disgusting notes - some dumbass who thinks it's funny to ruin my life. If I didn't know anything, why would I think that?"
